awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Initial Landscape Peopling
awd_abstract_narration:
Little is known of the adaptive strategies used by modern humans who initially populated early unfamiliar landscapes, or how much variation existed in these strategies – processes that can be revealed through archaeology. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate the strategies used by the first people to settle such a region. It was covered in glacial ice, meaning the early sites here are likely not far removed from the first expansion of people into the area, making it an ideal region in which to study adaptations to an unknown land. The results of this study will help illuminate the adaptive processes used by pioneering groups in the Americas and will have relevance to other peopling processes in human history. This project will contribute as well by using previously excavated archaeological collections: many archaeological sites are excavated but then never thoroughly analyzed, leading to a loss of research potential and money spent excavating and housing site collections, especially as available museum storage space declines. The use of museum collections is especially important in this case, as they may include rare examples of a fundamental process of human history.  

To investigate the adaptive strategies of the early populations in this region, research will focus on six sites found across the study area. These sites are part of a group of unique, large basecamp sites with complex spatial patterning that occur throughout the region. While these base camps must have been occupied soon after the region was populated, their exact relationship to the broader peopling process is still unclear. Stone tool raw material source representation and procurement patterns, as inferred from macroscopic source analyses and geochemical source analyses, will provide information on landscape familiarity and mobility patterns. Stone tool technological analyses, including tool and projectile point morphology, tool diversity, and tool use diversity, will be used to infer mobility patterns, site activities, and technological strategies meant to mitigate risk, with the assumption that risk minimization strategies will be more pronounced at sites in which people were less familiar with the surrounding landscape. By examining patterns and variation among these six sites, the researchers will be able to investigate the adaptive strategies of populations in a new landscape.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Little is known of the adaptive strategies used by modern humans who initially populated unfamiliar landscapes in Ice Age times, or how much variation existed in these strategies – processes that can be revealed through archaeology. Under the direction of Dr. David J. Meltzer, Anne Parfitt investigated the strategies used by the first people to settle Northeastern United States and Southeastern Canada in the late Ice Age. This region was covered in glacial ice as late as 10,300 years ago, meaning the early sites here are likely not far removed from the first expansion of people into the area, making it an ideal region in which to study adaptations to an unknown land. The results of this study will help illuminate the adaptive processes used by pioneering groups in the Americas, and have relevance to other peopling processes in human history. This project will contribute as well by using previously excavated archaeological collections: many archaeological sites are excavated but then never thoroughly analyzed, leading to a loss of research potential, and a waste of time and money spent excavating and housing site collections, especially as available museum storage space declines. The use of museum collections is especially important in this case, as they may include rare examples of a fundamental process of human history. 

In order to investigate the adaptive strategies of the early populations in this region, the researchers focused on six early Paleoindian-period sites found across the study area. These sites are part of a group of unique, large basecamp sites with complex spatial patterning that occur throughout the region. While these basecamps must have been occupied soon after the region was populated, their exact relationship to the broader peopling process is still unclear. Were these sites occupied early enough that the people in them were still completely unfamiliar with the surrounding landscape, or were the people in these sites already somewhat ‘settled in,’ having scouted this newly deglaciated region? Did the occupants of these sites vary in their adaptive strategies and behaviors, especially in terms of their mobility patterns, site activities, and how they used technology to safeguard against environmental uncertainty? Or, was their behavior broadly similar across the landscape? To answer these questions, the researchers investigated multiple variables. Stone tool raw material source representation and procurement patterns, as inferred from macroscopic source analyses and geochemical source analyses, provided information on landscape familiarity and mobility patterns. Stone tool technological analyses, including tool and projectile point morphology, tool diversity, and tool use diversity, were used to infer mobility patterns, site activities, and technological strategies meant to mitigate risk.

The results of the stone tool raw material analyses varied significantly among the sites. Some of the sites had primarily local material, suggesting a strong familiarity with the landscape, while others had material profiles suggestive of long seasonal rounds, possibly associated with Caribou hunting. Two of the New England sites had the same raw material sources represented at each site, while two of the Great Lakes sites also had the same sources, but occurring in different frequencies. In general, the evidence for raw material use in the sites in New England seems to fit expectations for people completing seasonal rounds, possibly in response to caribou migrations, and may indicate that these groups were already relatively familiar with the landscape through which they were traveling. The sites in the Great Lakes also may be associated with caribou hunting, but one of these sites is dominated by a raw material from 500 km away, which suggests that these Great Lakes sites may be more closely tied to the peopling of the landscape than those further east. 

The results of the technological analyses indicate that people at these early sites mitigated risk in some ways, but not in others. For example, people at these sites do not seem to have maximized functional flexibility, nor do they appear to have prioritized long use lives for their tools. On the other hand, all of the sites showed evidence that people were making tools and tool blanks that were highly portable, particularly by carrying flake blanks, which are an efficient way of transporting raw material. Overall, the technological evidence suggests that people in this region used a broadly similar, generalized adaptive strategy in terms of tool technology, risk mitigation, site activities, and projectile point manufacture and style.

Overall, in relation to the research questions above, people at these early sites may have varied in terms of their level of landscape familiarity- but they employed similar adaptive strategies, and similar behaviors, as they moved into and settled into the newly deglaciated Northeast.
